[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/legacy-move-compiler/src/command_line/mod.rs] [Function: get_move_compiler_backtrace_from_env()] [Environment variable injection] Can an attacker manipulate MOVE_COMPILER_BACKTRACE_ENV_VAR or MVC_BACKTRACE_ENV_VAR to leak sensitive stack traces containing validator private keys, consensus state, or other confidential information during compilation of on-chain governance proposals? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/legacy-move-compiler/src/command_line/mod.rs] [Function: get_move_compiler_backtrace_from_env()] [Information disclosure] Does the function properly sanitize stack traces before output, or can setting these environment variables expose internal validator memory addresses, cryptographic material, or consensus algorithm implementation details that aid in attacking the network? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/legacy-move-compiler/src/command_line/mod.rs] [Constant: MOVE_COMPILER_DEBUG_ENV_VAR] [Debug flag abuse] Can a malicious actor compiling smart contracts set MOVE_COMPILER_DEBUG_ENV_VAR to enable verbose debugging output that leaks sensitive compilation internals, bytecode vulnerabilities, or optimization patterns that could be exploited in deployed Move modules on Aptos mainnet? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/legacy-move-compiler/src/command_line/mod.rs] [Constant: MVC_DEBUG_ENV_VAR] [Debug bypass] If both MOVE_COMPILER_DEBUG_ENV_VAR and MVC_DEBUG_ENV_VAR are set to conflicting values, which takes precedence, and can this be exploited to bypass security logging or enable unauthorized debug features during critical governance proposal compilation? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/legacy-move-compiler/src/command_line/mod.rs] [Constant: MOVE_COMPILER_DUMP_ENV_VAR] [Bytecode dumping attack] Can setting MOVE_COMPILER_DUMP_ENV_VAR allow an attacker to dump intermediate bytecode representations containing unoptimized code paths or security checks that could reveal vulnerabilities in the Move VM execution engine used by Aptos validators? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/legacy-move-compiler/src/command_line/mod.rs] [Constant: MVC_DUMP_ENV_VAR] [Compilation artifact exposure] Does enabling MVC_DUMP_ENV_VAR expose compilation artifacts that could be analyzed to find gas optimization exploits, allowing attackers to craft transactions that consume disproportionate validator resources and cause performance degradation? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/legacy-move-compiler/src/command_line/mod.rs] [Constant: DEFAULT_OUTPUT_DIR] [Path traversal] Can the DEFAULT_OUTPUT_DIR constant value 'build' be exploited through path traversal in combination with other compiler flags to write compiled Move modules to arbitrary filesystem locations, potentially overwriting critical validator configuration files or consensus state? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/legacy-move-compiler/src/command_line/mod.rs] [Constant: OUT_DIR] [Directory manipulation] If an attacker specifies a malicious OUT_DIR value during compilation of a governance proposal, can they cause compiled bytecode to be written to sensitive system directories, potentially replacing legitimate framework modules with backdoored versions? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/legacy-move-compiler/src/command_line/mod.rs] [Constant: MOVE_COMPILED_INTERFACES_DIR] [Interface poisoning] Can manipulating the MOVE_COMPILED_INTERFACES_DIR path allow an attacker to inject malicious interface files that alter type signatures or function behaviors during dependency resolution, causing validators to execute compromised smart contract logic? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/legacy-move-compiler/src/command_line/mod.rs] [Constant: COMPILED_NAMED_ADDRESS_MAPPING] [Address mapping attack] Can an attacker manipulate COMPILED_NAMED_ADDRESS_MAPPING to remap named addresses to attacker-controlled addresses during compilation, causing legitimate transactions to send APT tokens or governance votes to malicious addresses instead of intended recipients? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/legacy-move-compiler/src/command_line/mod.rs] [Constant: SKIP_ATTRIBUTE_CHECKS] [Attribute bypass] Does enabling SKIP_ATTRIBUTE_CHECKS allow malicious Move code to include unauthorized attributes that bypass security validations, gas metering, or access control checks in the Aptos VM, potentially enabling unauthorized fund transfers or consensus manipulation? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/legacy-move-compiler/src/command_line/mod.rs] [Constant: SHADOW] [Shadowing attack] Can the SHADOW flag be abused to shadow legitimate Move framework functions or types with malicious implementations during compilation, allowing attackers to replace core staking, governance, or coin transfer logic with backdoored versions? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/legacy-move-compiler/src/command_line/mod.rs] [Constant: VERIFY] [Verification bypass] If the VERIFY flag is disabled or manipulated, can unverified Move bytecode be deployed to Aptos mainnet that violates resource safety guarantees, enabling double-spending attacks or unauthorized minting of APT tokens? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/legacy-move-compiler/src/command_line/mod.rs] [Constant: TEST] [Test mode exploitation] Can enabling the TEST flag in production compilation expose test-only code paths or mock implementations that bypass authentication, allowing unauthorized access to privileged validator operations or treasury funds? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/legacy-move-compiler/src/command_line/mod.rs] [Constant: SOURCE_MAP] [Source map manipulation] Can manipulated SOURCE_MAP data be used to provide false debugging information that conceals malicious code behavior during security audits, allowing backdoored governance proposals to pass review and get executed on-chain? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/legacy-move-compiler/src/command_line/mod.rs] [Constant: LANGUAGE_VERSION] [Version downgrade attack] Can an attacker specify an outdated LANGUAGE_VERSION to compile Move code using deprecated language features that have known security vulnerabilities, then deploy this vulnerable code to exploit validators or steal staked funds? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/legacy-move-compiler/src/command_line/mod.rs] [Constant: LANG_V2_FLAG] [Language version confusion] If LANG_V2_FLAG is enabled inconsistently across validators during an epoch transition, could this cause deterministic execution failures where different validators produce different state roots, leading to consensus failure and network partition? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/legacy-move-compiler/src/command_line/mod.rs] [Constant: MOVE_COMPILER_WARN_OF_DEPRECATION_USE] [Deprecation hiding] Can disabling MOVE_COMPILER_WARN_OF_DEPRECATION_USE allow attackers to use deprecated Move functions with known security flaws without triggering compiler warnings, making it easier to slip vulnerable code into governance proposals or framework upgrades? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/legacy-move-compiler/src/command_line/mod.rs] [Constant: MOVE_COMPILER_WARN_OF_DEPRECATION_USE_FLAG] [Warning flag bypass] If the Wdeprecation flag is not enforced during compilation of critical Aptos framework modules, can legacy insecure coding patterns persist in upgraded modules, creating exploitable vulnerabilities in staking or governance logic? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/legacy-move-compiler/src/command_line/mod.rs] [Constant: WARN_UNUSED_FLAG] [Dead code concealment] Can suppressing WARN_UNUSED_FLAG warnings hide intentionally unused malicious code paths that activate under specific conditions, allowing attackers to plant time-bombs or conditional exploits in deployed Move modules? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/legacy-move-compiler/src/command_line/mod.rs] [Constant: COLOR_MODE_ENV_VAR] [Terminal injection] Can manipulating COLOR_MODE_ENV_VAR inject ANSI escape sequences that perform terminal manipulation attacks on validator operators, potentially hiding critical security warnings or forging success messages for failed operations? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/legacy-move-compiler/src/command_line/mod.rs] [Constant: COLOR_MODE_ENV_VAR] [Diagnostic spoofing] If COLOR_MODE is set to unexpected values, could this cause diagnostic output to be malformed or truncated in ways that hide compilation errors, allowing buggy or malicious Move code to be deployed without proper validation?
